Award.AwardTitle: Frontera Travel Grant: Unraveling Hadron Mass and Quark Structure with COMPASS and COMPASS++/AMBER

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: For nearly four decades, the National Science Foundation (NSF) has played a leadership role in provisioning advanced cyberinfrastructure capabilities for the Nation's Science and Engineering (S&E) researchers. An important component in this investment is the leadership-class computing program that provides computational and data analytics capabilities at the largest scale to inspire transformative S&E discoveries that would not be possible otherwise. NSF's current leadership-class computing investment supports Frontera, the largest High-Performance Computing (HPC) system on a US academic campus. The Frontera system is deployed and operated by the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at the University of Texas (UT) at Austin. This travel grant will support the participation of researchers who have been awarded a computer time allocation on the Frontera system at a future Principal Investigator (PI) meeting organized by TACC. The award will also support travel for technical coordination between researchers and the Frontera project to ensure optimal and effective utilization of the Frontera system.<br/><br/>The goal of the PI meeting is to allow Frontera research users, as well as their students, to share scientific results, exchange practical lessons-learned, and present their overall experience from using the Frontera system. In addition to research presentations, the meeting will have ample time, as well as facilitated sessions, to promote increased interaction between Frontera research users and project staff. The outcome of the PI meeting will not only enable the Frontera project to better understand and serve the scientific research community, but also build a community to better represent the unique needs of S&E research that require access to NSF leadership computing facilities. To facilitate deeper coordination beyond the PI meeting, this award will also provide travel support to enable technical coordination between the research user teams and the Frontera project.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We study the nucleus of the hydrogen atom - the proton - with its rich inner structure of elementary quarks and gluons. Via the strong nuclear force, gluons bind the quarks together inside the proton. To explore proton structure, we break protons apart in particle collisions at the COMPASS experiment at CERN, the European center for nuclear research. The particles emerging from the collisions are invisible to the human eye and are therefore registered in large detectors, whose hit patterns are digitized and stored in a special data format. To interpret the raw data, they are processed on computers using complex reconstruction algorithms and input data bases, thereby translating the collected hits over time into trajectories of electrically charged particles and their physical properties such as charge, momentum, and energy. For the study of systematic uncertainties underlying the measurement, large data sets are simulated employing Monte-Carlo based methods. To remove biases from the measurement, time-dependent inefficiencies in the particle-trajectory reconstruction are studied.

The spatial patterns and momenta of the particles from the proton fragmentation carry information about the initial proton and enable us to create a dynamic picture of the proton and other objects composed of quarks: how do the quarks move inside the proton, in particular in the direction perpendicular (transverse) to the scattering plane, and what is their orbital motion?; are there spin-orbit and spin-spin couplings in the proton similar to those in the hydrogen atom, which give rise to its (hyper)fine structure?; how are quarks distributed in the proton?; and the decades-old question, where does the intrinsic spin of the composite proton come from? In the global context, the COMPASS data allow, together with data collected at other nuclear-physics laboratories in the US, Europe and Japan, to test if the modern theoretical description of these data is accurate and universally applicable to different types of scattering processes.

The particle-trajectory reconstruction, the data simulation, and the determination of detector inefficiencies are all highly CPU-intensive processes and can constitute a bottleneck in the fast dissemination of the results to the non-COMPASS experts and the public. The PI had in a separate grant secured petascale computing resources on the NSF-funded TACC supercomputer Frontera for productions of COMPASS data. The capabilities of Frontera allowed for an essentially faster processing of the experimental and simulated Monte-Carlo data and thus boost a timely publication of COMPASS results on proton substructure.

The grant reported about here was specifically for travel resources to attend the annual Frontera PI meeting, which were not used because the 2020 meeting took place on zoom in 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the PI reported there remotely. The overall Frontera project offered outstanding educational potential for about ten students and postdocs from the US, Europe and Asia towards building a community capable of using petascale computing including the handling of very large data sets, the usage of supercomputing grids, and high-performance computing.
